number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Good and entertaining remake of a classic with some inherited and some added flaws.The remastered DuckTales music draws you right into the game and you are eager to "press start", though you might encounter the first hurdle here, if you don't have a supported (read an Xbox360) controller. (Installing a utility like x360ce or xPadder helps, the keyboard is also an option on the PC of course.)The graphics are great, especially the animated sprites and while some reviewers criticized the comparably small number of different animations, especially noticeable in the cutscenes, I think it's fine for the scope of the project. Talking about the cutscenes, I consider them an added flaw, they are too frequent, interrupt the gameplay unnecessarily and require two button presses to skip them. No need to borrow the weak way of storytelling of a modern FPS in a classic. The voice acting is well done and the cast is mostly from the original TV show.I like the new 3D backgrounds as well, and I don't see why some reviewers think they wouldn't match with the sprites. The environments are clearly readable, which is important in a game like this.The uneven difficulty can be considered an inherited flaw, the levels vary greatly in difficulty, and the first on the list, Amazonas, surely isn't the easiest. When you play the game on "Easy" it's not too much of a problem, because you have infinite lives (making the mode arguably "Very Easy"), but beginning on "Normal", it can become frustrating, because if you run out of lives, you have to restart the whole level, all treasure gone. Though if I remember how many times I smashed my NES controller onto the floor, this remake is true to its roots in this aspect.The game is also really short and most of the playtime can be attributed to the overall unforgiving difficulty once you play on "Normal", "Hard" or the unlockable "Extreme" setting. Gameplay wise, the biggest addition compared to the original is a tutorial level at the beginning.DuckTales is easy to recommend, not only for the nostalgia, but because it's a very good game for the price. Sure, the cutscenes, will annoy you and the difficulty mixed with occasional hick-ups in the controls will frustrate you from time to time, but hasn't it been like this also 2 decades ago?Next stop, Chip 'n Dale Rescue Rangers, WayForward?

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												I actually have the original NES version of this game sitting in a shelf behind me. This was one of my favorite NES games when i was a child. At the time the cartoon was very popular over here in Sweden so there was no surprise that even the game did well.I was a bit worried at first when i saw that they were making a HD remake of a childhood memory. The first videos i saw made me go in to a nerdrage over how soulless the game seemed to be. It honestly looked like a crappy flashversion of my favorite game. But when i saw it for a good price on GMG i had to have it in my collection, just so i could say i hated it, which i diden't.This is a really really good remake of the classic game. The graphics, even if they were very different from the original, still felt really good. The controls were spot on as with the original and the music, oh my god the music. It is said that you dont mess with the classics, but the composers handled the original soundtrack with the outmost respect and made new classics of them. The new additions in gameplay also worked pretty well. They had to redesign some of the levels and for the most part it worked preetty good. The only downside is the mandatory tutorial level in the very beginning of the game. It's irritating when you are trying to beat the game for a second or third time, or when achivement hunting. But overall this ia a great game. They really gave the respect needed for such a classic game and made our old gamer hearts fill with a warm feeling of nostalgia.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												DucktTales: Remastered is a fairly good game that for the most part captures the awesome that was in the NES version.  There is alot of changes in this game.  The story is more fleshed out in a good way, it almost feels like a long lost Ducktales cartoon episode (with faithful voice acting included.) Its been awhile since I've played the NES DuckTales, but I swear the level design on some of the levels have changed as well, with even some added new levels at the beginning of the game and somewhat at the end.  I will say that the controls don't feel near as tight as the old verison, but not bad enough to not recommend the game.  One thing they did nail is music. MAN did they do a good job with the updated tunes, especially with the Moon stage and Boss music!  All and all if you played the NES Ducktales or have enjoyed watching Ducktales in the past, this game hits the spot!

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												DuckTales: Remastered is an absolutely wonderful game. I was a huge fan of Disney comic books when I was a kid and I have many great memories of the adventures of Scrooge McDuck and company. WayForward did an amazing job capturing the spirit of the comic books and of course the 80s TV show. The visuals and animations are excellent and the writing and voice acting are perfect. It's such a joy to hear Alan Young in peak form reprising his role as Scrooge.DT: R isn't a long game, nor is it particularly challenging (except for the final level), but it's exceedingly well designed throughout. The gameplay is varied and the controls are refined and precise. The boss enemies in particular are very well crafted, with fun, pattern-based attacks and just the right amount of RNG to keep things interesting without being unfair. I can definitely recommend that anyone who enjoys platformers pick this game up, even if they're not familiar with the source material. DT: R is a rare gem that's perfect for young kids but also will easily keep adults entertained and delighted.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												The game itself is pretty damn impressive. The graphical quality, real voice actors, music, cutscenes and enjoyable gameplay is quite worth buying it. But that's where the good parts for this game end.As most of the people have stated out, there is a crash bug in this game at the very last boss of the game. It has to do with some drivers by NVIDIA, pretty much, since I did beat this game on my old laptop back when I played it when it was brand new. However, owning my own PC with NVIDIA drivers installed does seem to make this game not worth owning, unless you want to keep repeating the very first five levels of the game. So in the end, I would give this game 9/10 for the nostalgia, but leave the 1/10 because of the crash bug. Good try, should've tried to fix it, though.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												I purchased this game alongside Mickey Mouse: Castle of Illusions during the Lunar Sale and played both the same morning so my review is for both games simultaneously. I didn't care for Duck tales. I wasn't a big fan of the show when I was a kid. (I was more of a Darkwing Duck kid) Right away I was disappointed that the backgrounds and items were not hand drawn like the sprites were. The sprites look great but they are placed overtop of very generic uninspired 3D backgrounds. Castle of Illusions, however, uses all 3D animation and it blends together wonderfully. The backgrounds feel as alive as the foregrounds. Moving Scrooge McDuck around is basic enough. Bounce on his cane to attack and occasionally swing at objects to bat them across the room. Things like climbing ropes felt strange as I could not jump from rope to rope but rather just fall and hope to catch ahold of another rope. Controlling Mickey Mouse was much more fun in Castle of Illusions. The mouse has ups and when you jump it's fun. Gameplay mechanics felt much more polished whereas Scrogge McDuck's controls were straight out of 8 bit NES era and not necessarily in a good nostalgic way. The cutscenes in Duck Tales come often and they are corny and repeat themselves unnecessarily. I found myself skipping cutscenes I hadn't even watched for the first time rather quickly into my experience. And this is the big one for me. Once you exhaust all of your lives in Duck Tales you have to go back to the very beginning of the level and find all of the items over again. Classic old school gameplay. Although when you add that mechanic you better be sure you have a strong game. When I died and went back to the beginning of the Amazon level, I didn't want to do all of that over again mainly because it wasn't that fun to do to begin with. In Castle of Illusions when Mickey was booted out of a room and made to start again I looked forward to having another go at it. That initial reaction to "starting a level over" in a game will always tell me whether or not I am enjoying the game.So in conclusion if you are into the Disney characters or just want a cartoon platformer and find a few Disney toons (Scrooge McDuck is basically a spin on Donald Duck) on your wishlist -- go with Castle of Illusions over Duck Tales: Remastered.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Ahh, DuckTales: Remastered. Just as a sidenote, I never did play the first one on the SNES. But yeah, as a Disney fan and generally wanting to play light-hearted cartoon-y games a lot, I was excited for this one. Having it gifted to me, I decided to hop straight into this and found that the presentation was fantastic. The visuals are top-notch, pretty much having been remade for this HD remake of the first game, and the music even better. With a New Game option awaiting me, I decided to go for that (and picked Easy mode, mind you!) but went back to explore the other menus later; there waiting for you to pick is a Gallery of sorts, which can also be accessed via the main game's "world hub"/level selector. Options for game configuration are there and play time. That, and a leaderboard which was quite fun to look at (how do people get through the game that quickly?)As for the actual main game itself, I loved it despite a few small flaws. The character models look brilliant and most of the time, work really well with the backgrounds. We start with a small cutscene and an opening level in the bank where you play as Scrooge McDuck (voiced by the original VA, who just so happens to be around 80, I believe) and you save Huey, Dewey and Louie from the evil (and a bit ditzy) Beagle Boys. In the process, you get to know about the main storyline; get 5 artifacts from around the world and then you'll have lots of treasure (or something like that). Woo hoo!So what do I think of the 5 levels after this? Pretty good. All different, long and have a great boss at the end for you to tackle, all while getting to know the hilarious Launchpad, 3 boys and Webby who tag along for the ride. Although, cutscenes aren't the best (but are skippable) as they don't show the character's mouths moving when they speak. Another flaw to the game is the sometimes dodgy platforming; whether it's cheap deaths from the weird jumping mechanics or taking a bit of damage when you really feel as if it's not your fault, WayForward definitely could have improved this. It just doesn't feel as great as the Mario platformers, for example (then again, most platformers don't).So after the next 5 levels (including THE MOOOOON, of all places. But I didn't see Princess Luna, so this is set after MLP season 3 apparently, heh heh heh), you get to save the 3 boys again and try and retrieve the treasure at Mount Vesuvius where you end up defeating Magica and also competing in some weird "escape the volcano" level that really felt bad, as sometimes Scrooge just wouldn't grab onto the ropes and wouldn't jump properly - and that kinda let that down for me, until I realised that there are a few tricks to get it right.Pros:+ Great level variety+ Voice acting is top notch+ Art is fantastic, so is the game design+ Good difficulty at timesCons:- Cutscenes aren't the best- Sometimes dodgy platforming- Length of game isn't great, despite decent replay valueOverall, pretty good game. 8/10 for me. Would (get gifted, but otherwise) buy again.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I had the original game on the old-school original Nintendo system when I was a kid and played it over and over.  It was a great game.  I was a bit apprehensive when I saw that they re-made it.  However, they did a great job with the re-make.  It's not exacly like the original but it has most of the same elements and it successfuly captures the feel (and the fun) of the original game.  I saw some people on the discussion boards griping about some glitches in the game when it first came out.  However I just now got the game (it's been out for several months now) and I'm having no problems whatsoever.  So I'm assuming the game has been updated/patched and the problems have been solved.Anyhow, my only complaint is that game seems a little short.  I've been playing for only a few hours and I'm already more than half-way through it.  But it's super-fun, so I feel it was still totally worth buying...especially since I got it on sale.  I'm having a blast playing it.  Enjoy!

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												I like the remake. I played the first one as a kid on the NES, and beat it plenty of times as a rental. there were some parts of the level design in a couple of areas that could have been better, but overall the game is pretty good and as fun as the original. the main issue was the frequent dialogue, lol. I liked it, it just happened a little frequently. There are challenges and leaderboards for the difficulty, loot gathered, and speed runs.  so there is quite a bit of replayability for people in those areas. as a 30-something that played the original as a child, I feel that this is one of the better remakes of classic games.  it's on sale for 50% off, and may have an 80% off day during the sale, so I figured I'd post this in case anyone was on the fence about it. It's a good grab.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2013
												If you absolutely adored old licensed Capcom platformers from the NES/SNES/Genesis eras, then there's not a lot to think about here, This game is for you. DuckTales: Remastered is perfect if you wanna relive those old memories with a new coat of paint, some updated tunes, and some of the kinks of progressing through the game worked out. It's the same hop and bop adventure you remember back then, only bigger and better. As for what this game may offer those not familiar with those older games or DuckTales itself, beyond the simple joys (I mean VERY simple) of hopping and bopping enemies and collecting treasures for a larger score, it may be best to wait for a sale. While DuckTales Remastered offers a solid recreation of the original game and is genuinely fun if you're up for something simple, the project just doesn't feel like WayForward went quite far enough in trying to make the project truly shine in the same ways that GRiN's Bionic Commando: Re-Armed succeeded. I won't call it lazy, because there's a clear love of the material here with the sprite work, reworked soundtrack, and tracking down all the original voice actors and actresses. At the same time, it does feel like the game had a lack of ambition, time, funds, or all of the above.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												Games like this are the reason why Steam should implement a neutral option to their review system. PROS: + Story+ very accessible+ Controls (for the most part)+ GraphicsCONS: - repetitive level design- very short (anywhere from 2-3 hours)- massive difficulty spike towards the end of the game- too many cutscenes in-between gameplayIn conclusion, if you're looking to get into the platforming genre for the first time Ducktales: Remastered for the most part is a template for the basics of the genre. But if you're looking for something longer or more difficult, I strongly recommend other platformers on Steam and even some from the same developer such as the Shantae series. Only get this game on sale or if you really love DuckTales.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Whether or not you've played the original game on NES, whether or not you even watched the show as a kid, this is a must-have platformer. It's more than just a fresh coat of paint, Wayforward has lived up to the subtitle "Remastered," removing or improving many parts, and adding cutscenes and two brand-new stages to give plot and context to events, voiced by none other but all the original voice actors from the show!What to do? Just grab onto some Ducktales!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Duck tales for the NES was one of the best games that ever came out for that system. Fast forward decades later, Capcom hasremade the game.I stress, this is a remake, and not a "remaster" as it says. HOWEVER, it goes completely in stride, and takes advantage of today's technology. The dialogue and voice acting is fantastic. The original is very well represented in this game, with so much extra when you do not consider thenew graphics, music, voice acting, and dialogue. I am talking about some bonus content, including a begining level not included in the original, plus a whole lot more.I recommend this game with a controller, especially an Xbox 360 controller. This game is casual, and if you played the original extensively, you will fly through this game. It is not a long game, but then again, the original wasn't either.With that said, I think it is priced fairly. I was given this game as a birthday gift, and I really had fun casting it live on Twitch, and beating the game. It really game me that retro feel, with a modern pollish, with very crisp and sharp graphics, and animations, with beautiful sound, and classic, straight forward controls.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Enjoyable most of time, great animation and voice work, nostalgic additions, and faithful emulation of the gameplay that made the original Duck Tales a lot of fun. The re-tuned boss fights are 50/50, with some being more monotonous than fun and frustratingly long. Cut scenes cannot be skipped or even advanced, not even the closing credits, destroying replayability as there are many, many breaks in the actions for brief-to-long interludes of dialog. The final level is a frustrating mess requiring 8-bit era manuevering and timing that does not play well with modern analog joysticks. Instead of a fun final romp to the conclusion it's a boring, awkward mess that feels out of place. I found myself rushing to try to get through it. And once there I was treated to a nearly ten minute long credit roll I couldn't skip past.If this game gets down to $1.99 or lower I'd say go for it. Otherwise there are much, much better games for your money and time.

												Во-первых, стоит иметь ввиду, что у многих настольгия осталась именно по второй части. А тут мы имеем ремейк первой, которая примитивнее второй, с её магазинчиком, апгрейдами и поисками карт. Поэтому почуствовать себя эдаким перепончатолапым Индианой Джонсом не выйдет.Что понраивлось:- старый добрый геймлей: прыгаем на клюке, пинаем ящики - всё как в старые недобрые 90'ые. Даже глюки перенесли с любовью =)))- уровни немного изменили и расширили, добавили немного новых... сюжет тоже немного переработали.- музыкальные темы перезаписали, но сохранили- графика довольно приятная- изменили механику боссов - некоторые стали гораздо интереснее и сложнееЧто не понравилось:- убрали дополнительные сокровища... приходишь на место старого секрета, а там ничего кроме алмазов и пополнения здоровья- смысла в поисках секретов и зарабатывании бабла особо нет - если только открывать унылые и вряд ли кому-то нужные концепт-арты на ачивку- тупые детские диалоги, которые возникают по кажому поводу и без повода... Мало того, что просаживают темп игры, так ещё и сбрасываются только через меню- играть на клавиатуре не то чтобы прям уж очень тяжело... но, если учесть, что 75% игры проходится с зажатыми двумя кнопками, проблемы с подкючением геймпада весьма не порадовали.Ещё немного мыслей.Непонятно, на какую аудиторию расчитывали разработчики. Детям игра будет вряд ли интересна, потому что и "Утиные истории" для них уже не актуальны, и проектов по-лучше хватает. Если на взрослую аудиторию, на зачем было делать её НАСТОЛЬКО детской? Диалоги примитивны (о том, что они вообще не нужны уже писалось) и шутки тупы даже для детей... Сгодятся разве что совсем для трёхлетних. На настольгии игра тоже играет весьма частично. С одной стороны знакомые уровни, знакомая механика... но всё какое-то чужое (нет, не вырос, запущенная под эмулятором игра по-прежнему доставляет).Итого, брать или нет. Я рекомендую купить. Как минимум в надежде на то, что игра окупится и разработчики примутся за ремейк второй части.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												This review was going to be about how I had never played the original Ducktales and how this game made me love losing, instead, I have to talk about the technical deficiencies of one of the best platformers I've ever played.When I first started the game, it had ludicrously bad framerate. I didn't understand at first. It looks like a 2D flash game for god sakes. I tried lowering the resolution, tried turning off the anti aliasing. Nothing.Turns out in some weird form of programming, the game is tied to your desktop. Specifically the AERO theme. I had it disabled on my copy of Windows 7 64bit, and this drastically affected the game as a result. Turning it back on was no big deal and the game ran at the framerate I expected in the first place.If only that was the end of it.The finale of the game (which is rightfully the trickiest part of the game) ends with two big middle fingers. First, the final boss will crash the game. Imagine going through that hell of a stage, seeing the finish line and having it cut short thanks to shoddy programming. The way to fix it of course if you're on a multicore is to start up task manager and setting the affinity of the game to 1 core. With that done... the game still crashes.Yes, even after all that, the game still crashes. After you defeat the boss, his death cutscene will for some reason, crash the game. I don't know why. I really don't. I had to resort to skipping the cutscene to prevent it.Imagine not only having finally beaten the boss, but for it to also crash right after, and that's still not the other middle finger.Right after that hard stage and that hard boss, you're thrown into TWO instant death scenarios.So imagine on the Hard difficulty, you defeat the final boss without getting hit once and have 3 lives left, only to lose them all to some of the cheapest, "gotchya" moments ever. Mega Man X3 had a similar ending and it wasn't even close to as punishing as this.So despite the game and the programming throwing every single setback they could, I still begrudgingly finished the game, cause its jumping controls are rock solid and were worth the pain. I think it says something about modern day gaming where playing a scottish duck feels more immersive than a soldier from Call of Duty or Batman in Arkham City, because what I wanted to do with my controller is actually translated on screen. I have never felt so connected with a character and how he plays in YEARS. It really doesn't take long for Scrooge to become part of your muscle memory, even for somebody who has never played the original. If there's something wrong with the way McDuck plays, I couldn't tell you, cause he felt perfect to me. He jumped how I wanted him, he pogo'd how I wanted him to. This came to ahead with some really tricky pogo jumps and having to avoid not only spikes but flying bat anemies just above you.The one thing I can tell you that felt absolutely crowbarred in despite never playing the original, were the cutscenes. These would be pretty dreadful without the original cast, but because of them, it really elevated the stilted looking material. It's not that it's bad, it's just that I wouldn't have cared if it were the Nolan North's and Terra Strong's of the world delivering the material. Scrooge sounds a little tired but that's to be expected for the actor's age, but he does nail it here and there. Launchpad sounds exactly like Launchpad and same goes for Huey, Dewey and Louie. I should say "most" of the original cast, because a few of the actors had people had passed away since the original cartoons had aired. I actually was shocked to find that McScrooge's nemesis, Flintheart Glomgold, was not voiced by the original actor. The only one that never felt right was Fenton/Gizmoduck. He did not at all sound like I remembered, which was even worse because "blathering blatherskite" is a pretty iconic phrase in both this series and Darkwing Duck, so he really stood out.The problem with the cutscenes beyond how terrible they look (which is an even bigger insult considering how great the original cartoon looked), is that to start up a level, fail, then have to start it up again is a pain. You have to skip about 3 cutscenes minimum, which requires you to hit start, hit A to skip, then repeat. It's just really annoying.At the end of the day, Wayforward continues to impress me with their mercenary work, taking a lemon of a job and turning it into lemonade. In the hands of a bad studio, this really could have gone wrong in everyway. Either in an attempt to update it too much and ruining the core gameplay, or just not doing enough work and delivering a subpar port job emulation, but it's quite clear in their rushed merc work that they couldn't deliver the type of love and attention they could for the PC port that they did in the game itself, but playing as Scrooge is undeniably fun and it's hard to not recommend this game, cause you can sense the enthusiasm for this in every little hidden treasure you find.The Pro's:+Rock solid controls+Devilishly difficult and rewarding to play+Good stage music remixes+A true loveletter to Ducktales fansThe Con's:-Prone to crashes-Concept art as an unlockable (Where's the NES version?)

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												There's nothing mastered about this game. It is nostalgia packaged with original voice acting from the cartoon, cheap 3D art for the environment and nice looking 2D art and animation for the characters.And that's exactly the problem with this game; it can't decide wether or not it should poke at your nostalgia from the TV cartoon, or from the NES video game so it decides to go for both.Seeing that this is an actual video game, I would've prefered if they spent more thought into the actual game elements and less so with the dozens of character conversations which is forced on the player.It is fortunate that you have the ability to skip 'cinematics', you do however feel less so when you have to replay a level, and then skip the three consecutive cinematics the game just has to deliver to you in order to get back to playing the actual game. Wayforward has gone through great lengths to make sure the character controls and level design feels like the NES game, but seems to have forgotten to ask if the old game actually had good level design and avatar game feel.Controlling Scrooge McDuck does feel good and precise, but it doesn't matter much when the levels themselves are simply annoying. The character is playing the game to collect treasures, you are motivated to find more and the game has diamonds scattered everywhere.If you enter a room and theres a corner where there's nothing: there's something there, go there, jump a little and diamonds will appear. The game habitualizes the player to nervously search through every nook and cranny for diamonds all the time. At this point you might as well make them visible to begin with, and not have the player go there, then leave the spot to then have the diamond spawn and then finally go back to the spot to pick it up. It's tedious, it breaks flow.And that's essentially what the game's biggest flaw is; it doesn't understand flow. All the running around, jumping, bouncing and searching for things which the original game did well, gets obscured by useless fluff that's only there to make us remember an old TV cartoon.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Nice graphics and creative remake of original levels. The music and voice acting are also very nicely done. The story is boring, and interrupts gameplay way too frequently to keep me immersed in the game experience. Perhaps the designers should've kept the game action going while voice acting happens on top. Since the characters are basically just GIFs with voice acting on top, I'm shocked you can't skip the current line of dialogue without skipping the entire cinematic. The writing is written for ages 6 - 10, so it's very hard to stay interested in what the characters are talking about. The game bosses' AI is very simple. Each boss follows a strict pattern and doesn't even take into account Scrooge's position onscreen. This makes every boss battle an exercise in simple pattern recognition. This is expected from the original NES title, but I would've liked to see a "remastering" of the challenge from the original game.The game feels repetitive after the second level is completed. I'd only recommend this for fans of the original show, and even then, wait for a Steam sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												What could have been a nice modern remake, turned out to be a fairly bad game, due to some poor decisions. The worst decision they made is the difficulty: easy is just a walk in the park, normal is a small nightmare (with double damage and 2 lives instead of infinite). I would have been way happier if they added some extra lives and kept the damage from easy for smaller enemies. Next up is the constant interruptions for some slow and tedious dialogue, you can skip it, but then you'll miss out on the... ehrm... story...  But is the gameplay any good? While the 6 different levels are completely different and have a nice design to them (which is supposed to be similar to the NES version), the game game suffers a bit from bad hit boxes and some details like being knocked back when you get hit (which can be annoying with 1 block platforms). But overall, besides all the mentioned problems in the review, I was OK with the levels. It's just a shame that on easy you're just blasting through them, and on hard keep restarting them.  As for the visuals, the only thing I would have liked was animated mouths (or beaks) when characters were talking. Other than that, it was like watching a very crisp cartoon (which is exactly the look it needs). The game also features some decent background music, although nothing special (except maybe the original Duck Tales theme).  In conclusion (tl;dr): This game could have been pretty good, if it weren't for the difficulty settings.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2013
												24 years later and still looks amazing. Duck Tales: Remastered is a blast from the past to any owner of NES. Back when games were amazing and nice to play, WayForward Technologies helps us to relive our happiest moments in one of the most memorable games of all time. Like the title suggests, its obviously remake of original game with better graphics, and updated soundtrack.Plus to original remastered in glorious HD levels we get also 2 additional levels for story progression. While in NES version there wasn't that of a story, here we get like a lost TV episode, with original cast from the show itself. While story can be just simple to understand it shouldnt be taken too seriously because its children show, so nothing serious or be amazed with. But most important part is redesign of original 5 levels. They are all back and looking better than ever. In addition the original soundtrack also is back with some addtions which makes it much better. We are used to the fact some games are being re-released as HD but in this case we get a bit more.You can also unlock some arts and other stuff if you are interested, or even swilm in Scrooge gold vault like he does in TV show. Now all we need for total nostalgia happines is 2nd Duck tales game from NES and maybe remake of Chip n Dale just for fun. If you didn't play original NES game, take this one. Its our childhood and looks at it's finest. 9/10.- Dima Voronovich, Russian Pro reviewer.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												The Beagles Boys had the crossed the line too far. They kidnapped his nephews, roughed up his money bin, and, worst of all, were having a treasure hunt without him. Scrooge McDuck would sit idly by no longer. Everyone told Scrooge that he wasn’t relevant anymore; it’s been over twenty years since Duck Tales and kids these days liked voxel zombie rogue-likes and Disney is only interested in mass-producing child stars so Hollywood can have a perpetual source of trainwrecks instead of making cartoons. Scrooge didn’t listen though, he didn’t care. All he wanted was all the swag the world had to offer him and the Beagle Boys’ heads mounted on his mantelpiece and nothing on Earth and the Moon would stop him on his blood-soaked journey. The world may have moved on without him but Scrooge will make sure that no one will ever forget that you never f*ck with a McDuck.Revised Edit: After playing more of this game I can't recommend it anymore. The final level is godawful and its like WayForward didn't even play test it. Just skip this game, its fun for a while but it pulls a Launchpad and crashes and burns so hard at the end.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												I hate it to say it, I really do. But this game is NOT woth picking up for full price. Honestly I wouldn't go much higher than 5$. Why? For all the prettyness and great voice talent in the game, the game sufferes from 2 majors flaws. 1. The hitboxes for both you and anything that can damage you is horrible. You can be just slightly off from hitting a foe directly on their head and take damage. This is made worse by the amount of 1-hit deaths in the game. 2. The games controls are terrible. This ruins the game for me. Its tragic just how bad they are when you see the depth the game has to it. How are they bad? They are unresponsive. One secound you are holding the pogo button bouncing along, and for no apparent reason you stop and will most likely die or take damage. You won't always jump or move when you want to as well. This made even the fun parts of the game a nightmare. Instead of enjoying myself I found myself watching my every step. The game has so much going for it but I can't reccomend it for 15$ when it just isn't polished.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game is a hot mess. The level designs from the original game are still as great as they ever were but every other thing in this game actively makes it worse than the original.It has this bizarre art style. Really detailed, well animated drawn sprites moving over ♥♥♥♥ing garbage simple 3d maps. It looks kind of like Paper Mario except it's actually appropriate for that game and is more skillfully done. This minor quibble is nothing compared to...THE VOICE ACTING! What the ♥♥♥♥? Scrooge's voice actor must have been mumbling 5 feet away from the microphone. Everyone else comes through crystal clear, but the main ♥♥♥♥ing character sounds like garbage. Which is kind of a problem. Because he talks a lot. Actually it might not be a problem because he says the same 5 or so unbelievably lame lines over and over for the entire game and I don't think being able to hear them clearly would actually measurably improve my experience.Oh, and get ready to mash start because this game has cutscenes piled on top of cutscenes. This is basically the textbook case on how to assassinate a classic NES game by adding all the worst♥♥♥♥♥♥from modern games to it. Play the NES version. It's still good. ♥♥♥♥ this remake.

number of helpful: 9 of 23 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Well thank God they included a "skip cinematic" option in the pause menu, cause man, this game really does stop every 30 seconds for some entirely unnessecary dialog or cut scene. Every time you pick up an item, meet another character, whatever, Scrooge stops in place for about 5-10 seconds so he can talk about it, making the entire game feel like an endless tutorial level. Imagine Mario stopping to have a short conversation with Yoshi every time he shows up, and making a little joke every time you eat a mushroom. Sounds pretty annoying, right? It is. The graphics, gameplay, & music are all great... while you're actually playing in between cutscenes, it's fun just like the original NES version. I just wish they would let you enjoy it all without interupting so often, because it really does ruin an otherwise decent game.  If you really want to check it out, wait until it goes on sale. It might be worth the $6 sale price, but your $15 could be spent much better elsewhere.

number of helpful: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it, WayForward, you make great games, but somehow i end up infuriated. Visually it's an amazing title, the artists really translated the Ducktales cartoon style brilliantly into a game. The whole presentation is impressive. There are just two things that bug me, but those bug me a lot: First there's the cinematics. WayForward seems to love cutscenes, they tend to add loads of those to their games. Having 3 cutscenes before you even start a level is already quite a thing. Then for every level goal you have another one. Then for the mid-level-save. You can skip them, at least, but even then they are still kinda annoying, as there is a screen fade each and every time when you just want to get on with the game! Come on, it's a jump and run game!Secondly the collision detection is very, very strict, to the point of unfair. It just doesn't feel intuitive. This is one place where they should have overworked the original NES-game. I remember finishing that original, but i guess back in the days i had more patience? Maybe my skills suffered, but i couldn't get myself to finish even level one...Don't get me wrong, it's a great game. The gameplay just feels a little outdated with such a collision detection.

number of helpful: 7 of 20 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Before I got to the last level, I was ready to give this a 6/10. So in my mind, the Metacritic user score of 66/100 isn't that far off. It's difficult to live up to nostalgia, and this game probably was facing unrealistic expectations from the beginning. The game is kind of fun, but it's not particularly challenging once you figure out where all the health pick-ups are. I enjoyed the boss fights, but the platforming elements were a little tedious.I was getting annoyed in the last level, in particular the last part (don't want to spoil the ending) because I thought it required a ridiculous level of precision. But then I finally realized that using the analog was the problem and switched to the D-pad, all was fine.Graphics-wise, the characters are beautifully drawn. Unfortunately, the same love and attention wasn't put into the scenes, where some of the things like helicopters look like they were drawn and shaded with Microsoft Word ... not even Microsoft Paint.The collectibles consist of art and music that can be unlocked through purchases using money you've gathered in each level. Unfortunately, you would need multiple playthroughs to get to the best stuff: the music and TV show art. And I didn't enjoy the game enough to play through more than once, so I was never able to access them.The unskippable cut scenes were the biggest grip that most people had. The developers added an option to skip them. I will say that the worst part of the cut scenes wasn't that they were unskippable (at the time) ... it's how utterly boring the dialogue was. Seriously, was the show ever that bad?I have to deduct a point in principle for the unskippable credits, taking the overall rating down to a 5/10. I don't generally mind unskippable credits, but 1) at least making it interesting, and 2) don't include every single person in all of Capcom! Seriously, the credits are obnoxiously long.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												I had my eye on DuckTales Remastered for awhile now, since I loved the NES game so much. Well it was on sale this week so I decided to pick it up and I don't regret it.It's a great nostalgic throw back to a franchise many of us 80's and 90's children grew up with. The music has been remastered wonderfully and I haven't had any problems with the controls. It's great that they managed to get (most?) of the voice actors back, that only make's it that much more special.The stages are mostly left the same, with minior changes to make it more action packed or intresting, I haven't had a problem with the stages, in my opinion it simply makes the whole experience more "refreshing".A complaint that seemed common with people was that the cut scenes cut away from the game and while agree that sometimes there's a little bit TOO much banter interuppting gameplay, it really hasn't been a deal breaker for me and some of the major cutscenes explaining the story and situation has been nice since the original NES game didn't really do too well of a job explaning anything, not that as kids we needed it, ha ha.To be perfectly honest, the only major grip I have is the art. The character sprites are wonderfully done, except the artists seem to neglect minor touches to the game, such as having the character's mouths move when they talk. The biggest issue I have though is that the sprites look wonderful, as if they were hand drawn and then everything else is a stagnant, ugly, pastel colored 3D rendered. The two styles class horribly and the artists who were doing the background and foreground work didn't even bother to have proper perspective when considering the sprites. In the introduction stage, doors, chairs and other background objects look to be 10 times bigger then character sprites and it's just lame and offputting. Does that ruin the game for me? No, not really, but it is a little offputting and really made me wish they would have just went that extra mile for attention to details. All in all, I'd pick it up, especally if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												This game is painful. As someone with fond memories of the original product from my childhood, all I can say of this newer experience is that the developers did too good a job copying the original game... right down to the mechanics from 1990.That just happens to be something you really, really should not do. Nobody wants to have games today like we used to in the 90's. There are no saves; The hit boxes are unforgiving as all hell; The game pulls super annyoing and unfair tricks on you all the god damn time.The only way you get through this game is by trying, and dying, a LOT. And starting from the very beginning, every single time. In a word, this game is hard. But it is not hard in the good challenging sense. It is hard in the frustratingly unfair, hair-pulling, rage-inducing sense.Also annoying: Too plentiful and slow-paced cutscenes that you have to rewatch every single time, although you can also skip them every single time.That said, it is beautiful to watch and listen to. But I know it's not something I'll be coming back to.WayForward focused on the wrong things to upgrade for 2013, and it's a shame.

number of helpful: 13 of 53 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I loved the DuckTales cartoon in the 1980s and so I hoped I'd like this remastered version of the original NES DuckTales game. Unfortunately, the developer failed to understand the current market and decided to design the game as if it were an NES game. Essentially, a lesson in frustration.First, you can't save whenever and wherever you want. I realize many games do this today, but it's a poor design choice. All it does is increase the overall level of frustration and repetition in a game. We've had the capability to save our games when and where we wanted since 1984 (see King's Quest), yet in 2013, it's a rarity because game developers are lazy.Second, the controls are awkward and that's even using a gamepad. The pogo jump, for instance, is hit-or-miss and rarely works right when you're attempting to do it over spikes or some other deadly landmass.Third, it seems half the damn game is cutscenes. Don't get me wrong, I like a good story as I grew up on classic Sierra Online and LucasArts Adventure games, but these cutscenes are unskippable and the story involved is barely adequate, even for a game based on a cartoon. [EDIT - I've been informed that cutscenes are now skippable. I don't know if this is a recent development or not, but considering I couldn't skip them, the above paragraph is remaining. That said, this factor should no longer be held against the game if cutscenes are indeed skippable.]Now I know some people will say I'm being unfair, as this game is essentially a remake of the NES title. To them I reply: Deal with it. This isn't the same game. Yes, it's a remastered version, but it's not the same. Changes have been made in every step of development, so there's no reason why a real save game mechanism, skippable cutscenes and a decent control scheme couldn't have made it into the works. Saying the NES game was like this is a poor argument, because the NES title had hardware limitations that modern consoles and PC do not.So what's good about this game? Well, it's DuckTales (which I imagine means something to you if you bought it) and the original voice actors have come back to play the parts they did in the cartoon. In addition, for those who wanted a near-perfect replication of the NES title, this is a masterpiece.In the end, I have to say I don't recommend this game. It's not terrible (I've certainly played worse), but it's very frustrating. While I'm sure that'll bring some gamers to a near ♥♥♥♥♥♥ state, it's far more likely that same level of frustration will drive most gamers away.

Posted: August 14, 2013
												Musical earbugs and great TV shows aside, DuckTales is best remembered as a 1989/1990 video game developed and published by Capcom for the Nintendo Entertainment System and Gameboy. Known for its five expansive levels, Nintendo Hard difficulty, and legendary soundtrack, the game was a smash hit and received great reception at the time, such as from video game magazines Electronic Gaming Monthly and Mean Machines.Nearly 24 years later, the game returns in the form of a remaster by WayForward Technologies. A hi-def polishing of the music, environment, and sprites; as well as adding new things such as cutscenes done by the original TV voice cast, unlockable concept art, and redesigned levels made for the current generation of consoles/PCs. The game’s download size, less than a gigabyte across the board, makes it a quick and easy download to your gaming system, regardless of platform.The first recognizable addition to the remaster of DuckTales is the introduction level that takes place in Duckburg mansion, under siege by the Beagle Boys. Through this level, WayForward does a good job at explaining the backstory behind the video game as opposed to the original, which left it up to the player to formulate.The plot mediates on a race between the Ducks and the Beagles to obtain various pieces of treasure. At first; it seems logical, but then the story begins to drift and eventually form holes when the Beagle Boys were nowhere to be found on levels such as The Amazon or in the African Mines, yet plentiful on The Moon and in Transylvania. Nonetheless, the cutscenes are almost always appreciated the first time around. After that, however, it would really help to have a “press X” to skip option instead of having to go to the pause screen every time after that. DuckTales’ noted difficulty setting is one of spectacle; the ‘medium’ difficulty system is probably not what you expect, depending on how much AAA games you might play. Instead of simplifying the game to cater to a more casual audience, its difficulty is roughly the same as the original (and NES games in general); that is, each setting is arguably a step ahead of today’s games. For the medium setting, it’s three hits, and you’re dead, two deaths and the level resets (not counting pickups). There is a lot of trial and error, and the game could easily be likened to Dark Souls or Winnie The Pooh’s Home Run Derby. Despite this, the game is for the most part fair, although in some sections (such as the mine shaft section in African Mines) it can be a brutally difficult experience by not letting you go left enough, plunging you to your death even after all of that hard work you spent getting that far. The game’s treasures (both in the literal sense and the figurative sense) are scattered throughout the level, and it pays off to explore every crevice available to you in the game and then some. It is even possible to obtain an extra bar of life (or two), depending on where you search. The sound design of this game is outstanding. From the background music of The Moon and The Amazon to the climbing of ropes, to even hitting a block with your pogo stick, it all sounds spectacular. Although the age starts to show in the voice cast, they perform their lines faithfully and with the same DuckTales flair as the TV show. Despite minor flickering issues, the game plays fine on the PC and has never crashed on me. It’s what a Day 1 purchase should play like, as opposed to a Bethesda-like assortment of glitches and bugs. The enemy AI isn’t wonky and, spiders aside, all of them are easy to deal with or to get past.DuckTales is a flawed gem with a lovable cast and a forgettable story. The latter is made up by a good soundtrack and good gameplay, and experienced gamers shouldn’t be too conspicuous about this title. It’s a challenge, but a very rewarding one. In that regard, it’s a great game and definitely worth the $15 (or less) retail price.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Hardcore nostalgia for this game. I had the NES version growing up. While nostalgia's great, there's a little to be said for the control handling in this PC adaptation.It loses some context sensitivity in Scrooge's office if you change the attack button to something besides the default; it will still say A on the floor spots, but you have to press your attack button (in my case, B) to first engage the art room, money bin, or supercomputer. Once you're past that initial part, the controls are normal again. A minor detail, but if you're going to "remaster" a game you'd better include the control and graphic adaptation not just the art, ya know?The reaction time on button pressing seems sluggish too. I use this same wireless Xbox controller for all my games and it does just fine. I seem to remember playing A Boy And His Blob (another WayForward game) and having the same issue.Otherwise, this is a great game! Same memorable voice actors from the cartoon and lots of good, solid game play.

Posted: August 23, 2013
												So, I beat this and I think I'm pretty confident in saying that it's the best remake of a retro console game I've ever played. If you have any appreciation for the platformer/action/adventure genre, please do yourself a favor and pick this up. Wonderful, crisp, responsive controls. Collectibles everywhere and bonus features unlocked in a way that makes those collectibles not feel like a chore to find all of them, but makes you want to get as many as you can to keep buying more. Amazing soundtrack, almost as good as the original, even better in some cases (Brilliant piano arrangement of The Moon at the end). Top notch voice acting and an adorable plot that fits beautifully with the theme of the show and the game. This game is a 90s kid/retro gamer's dream. What they expect the remake of their favorite game to be. WayForward outdid themselves this time, so please, go pick it up.

Posted: December 28, 2013

Posted: June 26, 2014
												A pleasant trip down memory lane, and as someone who experienced the magic of NES and growing gaming market in the 90s first hand, it brought a tear to my eye to see this game come back to life. However, it can't be denied that old things in new world have their new problems.Although the game's superb voice acting is a nice touch, forced custscenes during each level seemed to me as the devs were enjoying too much freedom with their new focus on "narrative". In most cases they interrupt the flow of the game, and it becomes a tedious chore to watch and listen to them. Imagine in Super Mario Bros., in the middle of running through a level, you have to stop and watch a cutscene. It gets old sooner than you think. The old-school sensibility is still there, and unless you're playing it on easy, you will die. A lot. And you will restart the levels after losing all your lives. A lot. I appreciate the devs kept this remake faithfully in-line with the original and captured that old games' frustration we remember, but I wouldn't be surprised if this difficulty curve becomes a turn-off for a lot of gamers today. (Checkpoint-and-quicksave-spoiled kids, this was the kind of video games that challenged our mind back in the day.) The remastered animations and music are fluid and stunningly gorgeous, and the new 2D-3D mix style of overall world design (reminiscent of Paper Mario) works beautifully well. For visual department, I could not have asked for more. The signature pogo cane action felt a little finicky and inconsistent at times compared to the original, however.In the end, I'm under an impression that WayForward and Capcom tried to win over both nostalgic old fans and newcomers by featuring charming storytelling and unforgiving platforming together, but the game ended up being confused and couldn't decide what it wanted to be. For those who have played the original, this game is a must-try for its beautiful visual improvement from 8-bit and nostalgia alone, but for those who haven't, let it be known that the only thing this remake does better than the original is the presentation and you're essentially playing the same game from the 90s. Take that what you will, but I don't think you will find the same fun you do from modern games, unless you have a bug for retro games.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												just a note: This is a review being done by someone who never played the original, as I came into gaming late  in the SNES era/early PS era, and am currently on my second play through.The pros of this game:The Music- It is stellar.  I wish they would come out with a soundtrack for this game.  The music for the levels are unique and suit the environment and tone of the game.  I can't say whether it is better or worse then the 8Bit rendition.  Thusfar, I've only heard the Amazon level music and the Money bin version, and I don't care for either of those, but that still leaves a few levels worth of music to go.Voice acting - Getting as many of the original voice actors from the cartoon as they could was a good call.  It made it seem like I was listening to the cartoon.Level design - Overall was fairly good.  While there was some sticky points that they could have improved on (the finale, for instance), the levels were beautifully designed, appealing to the eye, and offered just enough challenge to keep you from getting bored but not so much that the game was frustrating.  Ending aside.The Neutrals:Cut scenes - While I enjoyed watching them generally, they suffered from the fact that the characters were 2D in a 2.5D setting, and as such were limited in what they could do.  Personally, I think the game would have benefitted from cutting down the actual cut scenes to main points (as in, cutting out the ones for individual items) and animating them as 2D cartoons.Difficulties - There are multiple ones.  Nothing really all that special about it.The Cons:Lag - This may have just been an issue with my rig, but there was an odd amount of lag in the game.  While my computer generally is able to handle harder hitting games, it was bogged down by this game, which meant the game hesitated - oddly, this presented as pauses in dialogue and cut scenes, and as slower animation throughout the game, but somehow didn't hinder actual gameplay.The Gallery - While the gallery as a concept is excellent, and I love the idea of using the money you gain in the levels to buy the extras, the fact you had to unlock so much from one section to unlock the next area to buy from seemed silly.  To me, it seemed like a ploy to force you to replay the game, just to get the content you wanted - which for me was the music and background imagary.The ending gameplay - While I won't go into what the ending part actually was, I will say this:  In and of itself, the game ending was fairly good story-wise, but the execution of it was terrible when it came to gameplay.  This game had fairly even difficulty throughout, up until this segment - in which the difficulty randomly and suddenly spiked.  The overall design required a level of precision at points that made the game feel near impossible to finish, especially in comparison to the rest of the game.While the game does have its faults, it's a good game overall.  I bought the game on sale, but likely would have bought it at its full price had I found it at that.  $15 is a steal considering the amount of work that went into making this game, and the sale prices even moreso.  While I can't vouch for the nostalgia of the game, for someone who is a fan of Ducktales and the richest duck in the world, I would definately suggest at least giving this game a shot.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game. I love the TV show and the original game so when I saw this on the steam sale I was really excited, but the game just wasn't that great. Let's start with the cut scenes, there are way too many of them. I'm sure it is a common complaint but it is very much a problem with this game. To make matters worse, the default settings don't make it very clear on how to skip them. It took me way too long to realize I had to press esc and go the menu and select the option to skip the scenes. Though, it is good that they at least give you the option to skip especially on the first play through. The controls were okay, but they weren't perfect. There were a few times where I wish the game gave me a little more control over what was going on by making the controls a little more sensitive, and I'm not a huge fan of the drop down jumping that occurs when you are on a rope or a chain. I wish the character could have done a little more other than just kind of let go of the rope and fall in a general direction. Though, this particular complaint might just be a personal preference from me being somewhat spoiled by modern platformers with really great controls. The other thing I really disliked was the way the falling platforms worked. When I jumped onto a collapsing platform it would start to shake while the character was in the air. This didn't make a lot of sense to me. The platform shouldn't begin collapsing because you are in the air above it. The mechanic should wait until your character lands on the object in question. Not only does this make more sense logically but also I can't recall many games that do this in general.Other than that, I noticed a few graphical glitches when I played the game. Occasionally a random enemy would blink out of existence and back into view. It didn't happen all that often, but it did happen a couple of times. I'm not overly concerned with it though as it didn't really affect the gameplay much and was pretty rare.The game did have some positives. The voice acting was great and I liked the artwork. The levels were pretty much what I would expect from a remastered version of a game. I do think they could have done a better job of things. While I cannot recommend this particular game, I would like to see them remaster a few other older games and work on getting better at it before maybe considering trying to make new versions of some of these old games. I think there is room for improvement, and I would hate to see this stop because of a subpar attempt.

Posted: July 23, 2014
												Ducktales Remastered is a fine reimagining of the classic NES game. The five stages from the original game are faithfully reproduced in stunning hi-res graphics, the music is a phenomenal reimagining of the original 8-bit tunes, and the addition of voice acting (by and large using the voice actors from the old Disney cartoon!) tickles the nostalgia bone on an additional level.My only real point of complaint is the addition of a final, sixth level in which the game's end boss is found and battled. The problem lies not so much with the level itself, or even with the post-final-boss Metroid-esque escape sequence which is an incredibly unforgiving gauntlet of instant-death hazards that requires both memorization and reflexes to pass. No, the problem is that losing all of your lives during that escape sequence kicks the player right back to the beginning of the final stage, forcing him or her to slog through its entirety again. It struck me as unfun padding in an otherwise tight, high-quality game.That said, DuckTales: Remastered is a great nostalgia kick for people who grew up playing the original NES game, and it is overall put together quite well. Players who did not grow up on the original, however, might be put off by its comparatively short length, but anyone looking for a fun platforming romp should enjoy the game.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												As someone who grew up with DuckTales and played the original NES game when it was released, this was a fun blast from the past. It retains a great deal of the nostalgia of the original, while adding an updated look without going overboard. The music is lovingly redone from its 8-bit origins, and the gameplay feels much like it did on the NES (with the exception that the controller is larger, but that's only because I played with an XBox controller). The addition of the voice cast from the cartoon, makes for a nice touch too, as it was nice to hear them again. Made me pull out my DVD collection to watch the series again, and it the process, introduce my 2 year old daughter to the cartoon (which she now asks for all the time). I know many had issue with the amount of cut scenes added, but I didn't find it too bad. After your first play through, simply turn off cutscenes through the options and you're good. It did find the game easier than I did the original, but I don't know if that was me remembering the NES original being harder from the mindset of my younger, early gamer years or that I've just grown better at gaming. Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone; fan of the original cartoon or not. It's a nice bit of nostalgia for those who are and a fun, classic-styled side-scroller for all.

												So...chances are you either remember playing this game in the 90's (like me) or you had a look and thought oh cool!So here is a review based on both with pros and consPROS: The kid in me that once played the original-It is a great remaster of the classic and will bring back some fond memories-Still the same great platforming and same levels as the original.-Overall great game and for a fair price even at full price.CONS: The kid in me that once played the original-Something about the old 16 bit being remasted it looses some of the old school awe-inspiring charm it once had-The game has gone from being more of a game to this mix mash of game and movie. Posted: January 23, 2016
												It's literally Ducktales... remastered, and it's one of the best remastering of a game I ever seen. Ducktales is a 1989 action platformer on the NES similar to Mario that featured Scrooge McDuck from the TV show, Duck Tales. He travels the world to collect the treasures to become the richest duck. Ducktales Remastered is pretty much Ducktales except with new HD graphics, expanded story, voice-acting from most of the original cast from the TV show, and best of all, a beautifully remastered soundtrack. Ducktales had arguably one of the best soundtracks of the 8-bit era and being able to hear a remake of Moon was simply amazing. I whole-heartedly recommend this game.

Posted: February 8, 2016
												A great remaster of a great game - yet first things first: it might crash for you and I mean at the last boss and it might not be fixable. You can try to open up the task manager and set it to only use one core and it might just work, especially if you skip the cutscene before and after that boss, but it might as well not work. Fortunately, for me this workaround enabled me to beat the game.So, about the game itself: it contains levels that are reimagenings of the original levels and they're really good, they're well made, the music is great, the voice acting is good. Also there's now an additional tutorial level and another level as the final level (the story has been somewhat overhauled/made clearer) and you will still recognize enemies and parts of levels if you played Ducktales on either NES or Game Boy.One of the strongest points is the boss design: some now really look massive (as they should) and they are way more interesting in terms of attack patterns.So what's negative about it? Well, the crash bug that happens for many people (as I gathered it's mostly Nvidia users) of course and even when the characters speak, that's not animated. They might move, but they don't open their mouths. That's a shame. Other than that this game is great fun, and fortunately the cutscenes (which happen a lot and carry the story) are skippable (you wouldn't want to sit there and wait some minutes on your x-th playthrough).There are multiple difficulty levels, on most you can leave the game and come back later, there's (tested on a 360 pad) controller support, achievements and it might even have Steam cloud as it tends to go to "Synching" after quitting, though it has no cloud symbol in my library.If you feel like gambling on wether it will crash or not orare confident in your abilities in platforming and willing to skip cutscenes in order to reach the final boss before the 2h mark (which might be a little difficult if you watch every cutscene once and don't the rush the levels) so you can use the Steam refund system if it crashesyou should give this a look, when it's on sale.If it wasn't for the crash I could recommend it without needing to think twice.

Posted: February 5, 2016
												I wanna start this review off with saying this is one of my favorite games I've ever played.  From the moment you open DuckTales, it's hard to not be happy. Right on the menu screen they hit you with a nice 8-bit remix of the DuckTales theme, reminiscent of the original game. This is just a sample of the wonderful music that is still to come from this game. All the music is very true to the originals with great improvements with the move away from 8-bit. Now the visuals. The visuals are great. Every level is filled with color and with wonderfully done backgrounds. It gives all the levels alot of life. I love the look of all the characters and the animation. It makes me feel like I'm playing a disney cartoon. And of course, the gameplay. Now this just pulls the whole game together. Never before had i thought ofusing a cane as a pogostick do crush my enemies but now I don't know how iI played platformers without it. All the controls feel very nice and responsive. The levels are simple but oh boy are they challenging. I feel as if they don't make games as difficult as they used to because some of the levels in this game took me hours and numerous tries to complete but they pay off completely once you've gotten the treasure at the end. The boss battles are creative and challenging. Once thats all said and done, my personal favorite thing to do in this game may also be the most satisfying, diving into your vault full of money again and again. I could not recommend this game more.

Posted: December 22, 2015
												One year for Christmas I got the newer top loading NES and one of the games I got with it was the original Ducktales. The show had been out for a while and I was a massive fan and I still remember that day-after-Christmas morning, sitting down on the floor in front of the TV, blanket wrapped around my shoulders, everyone still in bed and loading up Ducktales (after blowing into the cartridge of course.) Hearing the midi version of the Ducktales theme, it was amazing. This was my favorite cartoon and now I could CONTROL my favorite character. No matter how many new games I got, I always went back to Ducktales. Must have beaten it over 20-30 times til I got my SNES. I knew that game inside and out and could play it blindfolded.So when I saw DuckTales Remastered...I was skeptical. The show, the original game, completely different era...Could you really remake that game with the standards, ideas and selling points of modern day games? The short answer is no, you couldn't. Call of McDuck just wouldn't work but this game doesn't try to do that. It is 100% faithful to the original game but with the addition of an actual story. It's like watching a DuckTales movie except you get to play the thing.Overall, bias aside, this is as the original game was: an extremely solid topnotch platformer with great enemies, varying levels and fun to fight bosses.Not a fan of Ducktales but like platformers? Definitely a must have.Fan of Ducktales AND platformers? Why don't you own this already.Also, as an ending note, one of the best things about DuckTales the game was the music, each stage had its own though of course none will ever be as popular and well loved as the Moon theme. They faithfully brought the music back, it's so amazing to hear those tunes remastered. I love this game, it was such a huge part of my childhood and instantly hit me right in the Nostalgia Feels.In closing: I could NOT recommend this game more highly.

While the music is good, it sounds like it's trying to pull out a bit too many tricks at a time.As the focus has been in making an accurate remake, I think the fullest potential could not be extracted out of the resources at hand. Therefore, what I would really love to see next is an original sequel with a more open world.

												Considering I remember quite a bit of the original NES game, I can say that this game is definitely a legitimate remastering, and if anything made some improvements here and there!The only real bad thing I can say about it is that there are plenty of cutscenes that pop up and can interrupt play, but it's thankfully minor. Posted: August 18, 2013
												Ducktales Remastered is a remade version of the classic Ducktales video game from 1989. I didn't remember much of anything about the game or the show when playing, so anyone who's afraid that this game is purely nostalgia-driven can worry no longer. As for anyone who has played the original, I'm not sure how much stuff is new/old.Ducktales Remastered is a classic platformer where your main goals are to make it to the end of a stage as well as collect as much money that appears as you can (you use this to buy art and music). Your moveset consists of pogoing on your cane (which jumps higher, nulls ground hazards, and can be used to attack) and hitting things from the side with your cane. Despite these basic controls, the game does a good job to employ them in the levels.The game is fairly short, consisting of seven levels. But on my first time, the game took me several hours. The game as a whole looks beautiful. There are plenty of nooks and crannies to scramble around to collect gems, and I think the levels are well-designed overall. Each level even has different items in chests and the like depending of difficulty. The remastered music for each level is beautiful, but you can still listen to the original, 8-bit versions if you want.Throughout the entire game, there are a bunch of cutscenes. And while the animations are fairly limited in these, they compliment the original voice-actors' voices. It feels like you're playing through an interactive DuckTales episode with each new level you visit. They're definitely charming and I've caught myself rewatching a few in future playthroughs. If you DIDN'T want to watch them again, you can chose to have most of the cutscenes skipped in future playthroughs. Scrooge also says a few lines throughout the game that are also charming albeit a bit annoying after multiple times.As far as difficulty goes, the entire game seems balanced up until The End. You're given four difficulties: Easy, Medium, Hard and Extreme. Easy gives infinite lives and you take half-hearts in damage while the others have lives and you take full hearts of damage. Extreme has no saves throughout the entire game, so if you Game Over, you have to restart. I recommend starting on Hard if not Easy, since Medium was harder due to little/no life drops.Now we get to my one huge problem with the game. The game stays at a nice level of difficulty throughout most of the game (some levels have tough bits, some bosses can cause trouble, etc). However, there are two segments after the final boss that I spent nearly two hours on trying to beat alone. First, there's this really tight upwards chase scene where you're likely to screw up a lot. Every time you lose the race, you lose a life. THEN, there's a segment where you need to quickly climb up ropes to avoid rising lava. However, a lot of the rope grabs are nearly-pixel perfect, and one screw-up means fiery death. Every time you Game Over (with 3-4 lives each chance) from those two points, you need to do the whole last level and final boss AGAIN. And with how unfairly difficult they are, you'll be doing it a lot if you're not on Easy. I refuse to play Extreme for this reason alone! If you don't like the idea of Game Over-ing, I highly recommend Easy first (if you want all achievements, you need to play it anyways for those 2 health upgrades), then moving onto Hard when you're used to everything. Overall, DuckTales Remastered is a solid game that I would recommend at full price. As awful as it is, I won't let The End's unfairness spoil the rest of the game. I'm sure that, Ducktales fan or not, the game's level designs and mechanics will make any platformer fan happy while the music, art, and cutscenes will make it memorable. Achievement hunters can also rejoice, as the gameplay is severely lengthened if you go for those. It's a great game that I hope people don't skip out on because of the press's overall negative reviews.

Posted: November 5, 2013
												Ducktales: Childhood Restored would be a more appropriate title for this gem of an experience. Replay the game that helped entertain a generation in a format driven by the voice of the Ducktales cast on an adventure to find lost relics all over the world. Level design remains unchanged though side-missions must be accomplished for many of the zones to move forward, all progressed by the aforementioned voiced cut-scenes. Reimagined boss battles help to create a living world filled with d-d-d-danger as you guide Scrooge to each treasure. As nostalgic as I am about this game, it truly does a wonderful job of bringing classic side scrolling action to a new generation of gamers while staying true to it's roots. If you loved the Capcom created Disney games of the NES, SNES, MS, or GEN; this game is a must have introduction to your collection. What other game features a wealthy beyond reason adventuring duck-man on a journeyto exotic locales? Ponytales? Cottontales? No, Ducktales!

Posted: January 25, 2016
												This is one of those times I wish I could give a positive review, but over the course of playing, too many things nag at me.I have such a nostalgia factor with this series (loved it as a kid), and I probably will pick it up now and again to try and complete it, just for old times sakes...but it's already feeling like a chore. -The game has been out for years, and yet there isn't even a built in menu for sound/music or windowed mode. The player has to know the "shortcuts" offhand.-Controls are clunky, but given the game being emulated, it can be forgiven. What is annoying though are the sometimes too unclear hitboxes (did I hit that? I'm clearly not standing on it).-Hilariously bad design with quick fixes. Eg. On the Amazon level, once I beat the boss, the camera panned out to show that the boss stage ceiling was gone, and in mid pogo-jump, Scrooge went sailing out of the arena, and had to be teleported back for the cutscene to continue; clearly someone came across this bug before me.-Game breaks when I try to navigate from some parts of the office.-Main Menu has some noticeable input delays. I would hazard a guess that it's most likely from amateur timers on when to read inputs. (the game will read inputs long before the options show themselves).-Apparently there has been a game breaking bug near the end of the game, that has still not been fixed after all this time (not for my graphics card fortunately, but it's worth noting).Really just ugh... I got this on sale, because I knew I didn't want to shell out $15 for this, and I still feel bad. It could be a good game with just a little bit of polish. They were literally handed gold: Take a solid game and just update it,but somewhere along the way they just goofed it all up.There aren't 'Meh' Recommendations though on Steam, so this gets a painful 'No' from me.Blow me bagpipes!
